## Mark Twain's Mississippi River Background

Mark Twain (Samuel Langhorne Clemens) was born in 1835 in Florida, Missouri, and grew up in the Mississippi River town of Hannibal, which would later serve as the inspiration for many of his literary works, including Tom Sawyer. Twain describes his boyhood in Life on the Mississippi, stating that "there was but one permanent ambition" among his comrades: to be a steamboatman.

## Steamboat Career and River Experience

At 21, Twain took passage aboard the Paul Jones from Cincinnati to New Orleans, enacting his boyhood dream. He persuaded Horace Bixby to teach him piloting, a 17-month apprenticeship. Steamboat pilot Horace E. Bixby took Twain on as a cub pilot to teach him the river between New Orleans and St. Louis for $500. Twain studied the Mississippi, learning its landmarks, how to navigate its currents effectively, and how to read the river and its constantly shifting channels, reefs, submerged snags, and rocks.

Twain worked as a steamboat pilot on the Mississippi River before the American Civil War and continued until the Civil War broke out in 1861, when traffic was curtailed along the Mississippi River. Piloting also gave Twain his pen name from "mark twain," the leadsman's cry for a measured river depth of two fathoms (12 feet), which was safe water for a steamboat.

## Influence on Tom Sawyer

Twain's experiences in Hannibal and on the Mississippi were used in his writings: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876), Life on the Mississippi (1883), and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1884). Tom Sawyer was also captivated by the Mississippi, living close to the river and using it for fishing and boating in his spare time. Twain's interests in the outdoors, particularly the Mississippi River that he had lived so close to, had a considerable effect on what Sawyer's interests were to be in the novel, as he knew a lot about exploring and what the outdoors were like in Missouri during the 1800s.

## Personal Tragedy and River Impact

In 1858, Sam encouraged his younger brother Henry to work with him and arranged a post as assistant clerk on the steamboat Pennsylvania. Two days behind his brother on the river, Sam received the awful news of a boiler explosion on the Pennsylvania. Henry, fatally injured, was taken to a makeshift hospital in Memphis and succumbed to his wounds eight days later. Twain was guilt-stricken and held himself responsible for the rest of his life.

## Literary Legacy

No engineer, author, pilot, poet, inventor or artist can claim a greater role than Mark Twain in making the Mississippi River known and loved throughout the world. No other man in the world is so universally identified with riverboating; Twain made the Mississippi known to the world and his inspired genius put the Father of Waters in the center of American lore. Twain once recalled getting to telling "about the old Mississippi days of steamboating glory and grandeur as I saw them from the pilot house," which became "Old Times on the Mississippi" and later the basis for Life on the Mississippi.

The Mississippi River and steamboat experiences were fundamental to Twain's identity as both a person and writer, directly shaping the authentic river settings and childhood adventures depicted in Tom Sawyer.
